Dr. Harry J. Skornia, Executive Director
National Association of Educational Broadcasters
14 Gregory Hall
University of Illinois
Urbana, Illinois
Dear Dr. Skornia:
At the suggestion of Kenneth D. Wright, I am
writing to you in regard to our efforts to develop creative
radio programing activities on this campus.
This is a small university, and we do not have
transmitting equipment. However, we have just acquired modem
studios, and the local radio station, WREL (250 watts) is most
interested in transmitting any educational programs that we
can produce. We have had a news and commentary program on the
air for a number of years, and last year we began a new series
of student-produced documentaries, dramatizations, panel dis¬
cussions, and other types of programs. None of these programs
is sponsored, and no money is involved in any way.
With our limited student enrollment, it is
difficult for us to sustain a regularly scheduled program
throughout the year, and I have been wondering whether pro¬
grams of unusual interest produced by members of your
association might be available to us for occasional use?
We are trying to build up listener interest and enthusiasm,
and would be grateful for your help.
Very sincerely yours.
0. W. Riegel
